post.body:
Many urls these days throw ?ref=eib5p7tSeOo_23_0acaec6551517ed6e12302aff5ca34eib5p7tSeOo_23_0acaec6551517ed6e12302aff5ca34 after the necessary portion, so analytics can track from where people clicked through...but it also means that "they" are able to tell that when @kek posts an article about Human cloning that he used the same "ref" url that was posted on Stormfront 4 hours earlier...so that's where he found it.

Privacy-wise, it would be nice if we were able to just automatically trim anything with ?ref= in the url.

body:
Yes, the parts that are true. Not the forgeries James, 1 & 2 Timothy, Titus, and Jude, probably 1 & 2 Peter, Hebrews, Colossians, Ephesians, and 2 Thessalonians (and possibly Revelation and the Johannine epistles). Or the obvious additions to Paul's letters especially in 1 Corinthians. I never said I didn't believe, but the bible != the word and that is just everyone's misguided assumption (the real word is very clearly identified at the beginning of John, and it's not the bible--so if you think it's the bible, you ironically don't believe the bible). People jump through many confusing hoops to try and get them not to contradict everything else even though all the places that do that are the ones that have a lot of evidence of not being written by who they say they were. That they were forgeries is pretty obvious and makes way more sense than a confusing mess of twisting opposing passages to agree with each other. There's also the possibility that even a true author is simply wrong about something. I mean come on, even the closest disciples were called fools more than anyone else and were absolutely clueless most of the time, can you really trust them 100%? These writings are good for reading but people barely even read the gospels, and they're the ones that literally document everything we need to know. Putting humans on the same level of authority especially when there are malicious forgeries among them creates tons of confusion and contradictions, perverting the very simple message found in all 4 gospels, and that is what we are told to follow, not "the bible" that wasn't even put together until 400 years later. Everything in the bible makes so much more sense when you realize this. You will not find "the bible" in the bible, not even in the forged books, and every canon list and books contained in manuscripts before 382 differs wildly from each other.

I used to think the same way as you and believe everything included in the canon was 100% accurate, but after I started reading even just a little bit of it I realized I'd been tricked and had been getting spoonfed the snippets that were convenient for certain agendas. I later found that all the historical evidence aligns with my suspicions. We removed the apocrypha, I don't see how this is any different. It's not like they stop people from receiving or anything but it does make everything way more complicated and can be misleading.

body: That doesn't mean the bible is perfect. The majority of it isn't even God at all, but merely writings by famous believers. And even the ones that are, the written record isn't what's faultless, but rather what they were recording. Lastly, a few of the books, like genesis, are compilations of oral or written records, basically historical documentation, and don't have much moral value. Differing versions of stories were included and were all appended into a master text. This is why contradictions like the creation story in genesis 1 and 2 exist and have different authors.

parent.body:
If it isn't fair, then women maybe shouldn't compete in the first place. The evolutionary purpose of watching sports as entertainment is to have an example of the competent in an area and establish a hierarchy that determines it. If you watch a handicapped version you are fooling yourself with some useless meta purpose. Does it mean nobody should watch lower leagues? Not necessarily but  it's with the prospect potential of them advancing, or just relatives or someone you know directly.

Just saying what seems rational to me. Of course if there's a demand for women only sports then who am I to deny that supply.

parent.body: No, polytheist, Paul and Jesus didn't teach the same gospel or soteriology. And James is meant to be edifying, not a gospel account. It's also a refutation of the Pauline ideas that were clearly already circulating. Notice from Paul's own epistles how there's a dissenting fraction to Paul, and how even the communities Paul visits and writes to rejects and abandon his teachings. But not even Paul promised salvation to idolaters anyway.
